title: Zooarchaeology by Mass Spectrometry (ZooMS) for bone material - Acid soluble protocol
title_html: Zooarchaeology by Mass Spectrometry (ZooMS) for bone material - Acid soluble protocol

source.body:
General Information:
  1. We recommend to use glassware for buffers and solutions and no long-term storage in plastic containers and/or tubes.
  2. TFA, HCl and ACN stock solutions should be handled under a fume hood only.
  3. Always label all chemicals with the compound name, concentraion and the date.
  4. Chemicals are prepared with water from an ultrapure water system (e.g. Milli-Q water, see materials list)

source.description:
Hydrochloric acid (HCl) (Shelf life: 6 months at
)

source.body: Handling of HCl should be performed under a fume hood because of its corrosive properties. HCl can cause severe skin burns, eye and respiratory irritations. Don´t touch your skin or eyes with contaminated gloves and change them immediately.

source.description:
For 1000 ml of 0.6 M HCl, add
of
HCl to
ultrapure water carefully. Mix gently.

source.body: Please always calculate the needed amount of HCl stock solution you need since this is dependent of the specific compound density.

source.description:
Ammonium Bicarbonate (AmBiC) buffer,
(Shelf life: 6 months at
)

For 1000 ml, weigh out
of AmBiC powder and transfer it into a clean glass bottle.

Dissolve the AmBiC in
of ultrapure water and mix by genty inverting.

Fill up to
with ultrapure water and mix by gently inverting.

Trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) (Shelf life: 6 months at
)

source.body:
Triflouroacetic acid (TFA) is very hazardous (corrosive)! Handling should only be performed under a fume hood.
Prepare this solution in a brown glass bottle since TFA is slightly light sensitive.
Always pipette water first, then add the acid slowly!
Repeated used of plastic pipettes in TFA stock solutions causes plastics to build up in the TFA stock solution and can interfere with mass spectrometry, therefore ALWAYS use a glass pipette/syringe for TFA.

source.description:
Dilute
TFA stock solution using a glass syringe/pipette (no plastic) in
ultrapure water and mix carefully.

Wash solution:
TFA in ultrapure water (Shelf life: 6 months at
)

For 1000 ml, add
of TFA to
of ultrapure water and mix by gently inverting.

Conditioning solution:
TFA in
Acetonitrile (ACN), (Shelf life: 3 month at
)

source.body: ACN is a volatile compound and if there is too much headspace in the storage bottle the concentration of ACN in solution goes down over long-term stoorage. We recommend not to store small solution amounts in large bottles over a long period of time. Either prepare new conditioning solution or store the remaining solution in smaller bottles.

source.description:
For 1000 ml, mix
ACN with
ultrapure water.

Add
of TFA carefully and mix by genty inverting.

Trypsin solution (Stable once resuspended for 1 month at
)

Freeze dried Trypsin (
) is resuspended in
of Trypsin resuspension buffer (included in Trypsin Kit or per manufactures instructions). The final concentration is now
.

Transfer the solution in a labelled 0.5 ml tube and store at
.
Weighing out the sample

source.body:
General information
  1. All steps should take place in a dedicated wet chemistry laboratory.
  2. Wipe down all surfaces with 1. ultrapure water, 2. 70% (v/v) ethanol).
  3. Alliquot out the reagents you will need (HCl).
  4. Needed after proper bone material deminaralization (see step 13): Aliquot out the reagents you will need (AmBic).

source.description:
Archaeological samples: Weigh out
-
of bone chips or ~
bone powder into a microcentrifuge tube labelled with the sample name, date and your name. Record the weight.
Modern samples: Weigh out
-
of bone chips or ~
bone powder into a microcentrifuge tube labelled with the sample name, date and your name. Record the weight.

Acid Demineralization (destructive)
Add
of cold (
)
HCl to the sample (or enough acid to cover the sample completely) and place the tubes in the fridge at
. Leave until demineralization is complete (bone becomes flexible/ spongy and no bubbling is visible anymore).

source.body: This may take 1 day to 2 weeks for specific sample types. Less time will be needed for bone powders (4-10 h).

For samples with good collagen preservation, complete demineralization is not necessary. Please be aware that the more the collagen remains in acid the more it breaks down. Hence monitor samples carefully at this stage to reduce protein loss.
Don´t forget to prepare blanks at this point! This should be empty tubes with only HCl added. Perform every step with the blanks, which you do with the actual samples.

source.description:
Centrifuge the sample for
to settle the bone and (heavier) collagen to the base of the tube.
Remove the acid supernatant into a new tube. We recommend to label this tube with the sample number and the suffix "AC",

source.body: Do not disturb the bone residues from your sample with the pipette.

If you want to analyse the acid insolube collagen fraction (please see the protocol "Zooarchaeology by Mass Spectrometry- Acid insoluble protocol") you should use this bone chip/bone powder fraction and store it at .

source.description:
Buffer exchange
Place 30 kDa ultrafilters into labelled tubes.

Centrifuge at
until acid has been pushed through the filter. This can take between
and
.

source.body: Put on cap and place filters into the centrifuge with the cap strap toward the center of rotor, this ensures the special shaped ultrafilters will fit properly into the centrifuge.
You should not let the filter dry out during this stage. Small amounts of liquid above the filter are fine.

source.description: Discard the flow-through.

Trypsin Digestion
Add
of
trypsin solution to the “EXT” labelled tube.

Incubate sample overnight at
(approx.
-
).

Centrifuge your samples
after incubation.

Aliquot out the TFA you need and add
of
TFA to stop the trypsin.

source.body: The peptides can be purified using a C18 ZipTip. If not extracting immeditely, the samples can be stored in the freezer at at this point.

source.description:
Preperations for C18 ZipTipping
For each sample you must prepare separate tubes of wash and conditioning solution. Prepare as follows:
One tube per sample containing
conditioning solution (or you can just use a common reagent reservoir - label with "C")
One tube per sample containing
wash solution (label with "W")
One tube per sample with
conditioning solution- this tube is to collect your purified peptides. We recommend to label it with the prefix “COL” and the sample name.

source.body:
General information:
During your extraction your peptides are bound to the C18 filter sitting in the pipette tip (ZipTip).The peptides then need to be washed and eluted. Therefore, subsequent wash and conditioning solutions will be ‘contaminated’ with your sample and so solutions after the sample has been bound to the C18 filter and cannot be used for more than one sample.

source.description:
C18-ZipTipping
Purify your peptides using the C18 ZipTip from the digested “EXT” sample as follows:
Rinse tip twice with
of conditioning solution and discard.
Rinse tip twice with
of wash solution and discard.
    Rinse tip twice with
    of wash solution and discard.
    Elute sample into the prepared ‟COL” labelled tube with the prepared
    of conditioning solution and pass through tip at least 5 times.

source.body: Before use, each tip needs to be conditioned. A separate tip is used for each blank and sample. The pipette should be set at and the volume NOT changed during the time. Be careful to avoid pulling air through the filter, especially at the steps with only of solution. We recommend to use an extra ZipTipping Only pipette as repeated use of the filters pulls the pipettes out of calibration.
Be careful not to push air through the C18 filter (never go past the first stop point of the pipette)!
The sample(s) are now ready to be spotted on the MALDI plate. If not spotting immediately, store sample(s) in freezer at .

source.description:
Add
of
AmBic and centrifuge at
until AmBic has passed through filter. This can take between
and
.
Discard the flow-through.

Add
of
AmBic to the filter and mix carefully by pipetting.

source.body: If your sample amount is limited or if less sample then recommended was available, use 50 µl of AmBic.

source.description: Label two new sets of microcentrifuge tubes in the meantime.

source.body: These tubes are to cellect the AmBic supernatant from your filter (see step 12.8). We recommend to label one set with the suffix “EXT” (extract) and the sample name and the second set with the suffix “SE” (second extract) and the sample name. If you are going to use 50 µl of AmBic for eluting the collagen from the filter (see step 12.7), only the EXT tube is needed.

source.description:
Transfer now
of the AmBic supernatant to the “EXT” labelled tube and the remaining
supernatant to the “SE” labelled tube.

source.body: The “SE” labelled tube serves as back up and can be stored at . Adjust the amounts of "EXT" and "SE" if less AmBic was used ( see step 12.6 and see the note).

source.description:
Take
of acid supernatant and put into a 30 kDA ultrafilter.

source.body: Take care not to touch the tip to the membrane.
For well-preserved collagen samples a 30 kDA ultrafilter is sufficient. Smaller sized filters easily get clogged. For poorly preserved collagen, a 3 kDA or 10 kDA ultrafilter can be considered.

materials.name: Trifluoracetic acid for HPLC ACROS organics
Ammonium hydrogen carbonate 98 % pure ACROS Organics
Hydrochloric acid fuming 37% for analysis EMSURE® ACSISOReag. Ph Eur

description:
This collection details the different established protocols for Zooarchaeology by Mass Spectrometry (ZooMS) for use on archaeological bone. ZooMS allows for taxonomic identification by the peptide mass fingerprinting of collagen type I. These protocols can be used individually or combined depending on the preservation, sample size, and ability to do destructive analysis. All the protocols are optimized for bone as the starting material.
In the acid soluble protocol bone is pretreated with hydrocholoric acid. The acid is removed and filtered leaving the collagen which is then digested with trypsin. The peptides are purified using C18 ZipTips. This protocol can be used in conjuntion with the acid insoluble protocol which analyzes the bone shaddow left after the acid is removed.
This protocol is suitable for a wide range of preservation conditions from very good to poor preservation. It works in cases where the bone is too fragile or the preservation is too poor for a collagen shaddow to remain after demineralization. The ideal starting volume is 10-20mg of bone as a powerder or a bone chip, but in cases of very poor preservation, a larger starting volume may be required.
If you are using this protocol, please cite the DOI for the protocol and the following two papers on which it is based:
Buckley, M., Collins, M., Thomas-Oates, J., & Wilson, J. C. (2009). Species identification by analysis of bone collagen using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionisation time-of-flight mass spectrometry. Rapid Communications in Mass Spectrometry: RCM, 23(23), 3843–3854. https://doi.org/10.1002/rcm.4316
van der Sluis, L. G., Hollund, H. I., Buckley, M., De Louw, P. G. B., Rijsdijk, K. F., & Kars, H. (2014). Combining histology, stable isotope analysis and ZooMS collagen fingerprinting to investigate the taphonomic history and dietary behaviour of extinct giant tortoises from the Mare aux Songes deposit on Mauritius. Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology, 416, 80–91. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031018214003071
